comments.text:
+ADubey
i am not defending monsanto. big companies are big companies, they try to 
make money, thats capitalism. you can say the same for hospitals in 
america. a hospital in america isnt there to treat sick people, its there 
to make money. that doesnt mean making people healthy is evil. its the same 
thing here. the science behind it is great, just like the science behind 
fixing a broken arm or a vaccine for small pox is great, capitalism just 
muddies the water

the problem is people who are opposed to big businesses, and rightfully so 
i think (i am one step away from communist myself) end up shifting that 
anger onto the wrong thing. the iphones apple is making arnt evil, the 
slave wages they pay their staff are, and genetic modification of crops 
isnt evil, it has saved countless children from blindness, the people that 
exploit this technology to muscle small farmers out of business and all 
other seed manufactures for no benefit are. the anger is justified though 
misguided

also, it isnt just monsanto that has people in the government. the banks 
have people in government, lockheed, boeing, all sorts of giants. not long 
ago america made the biggest military contract in history for a complete 
piece of junk aircraft that the designer himself has said in interviews is 
worthless. spaceX lost a contract to another company who took the contract 
at a SIGNIFICANTLY higher rate, all because spaceX refused to higher one of 
the government officials that would soon be retiring, costing taxpayers 
billions. again, is the problem REALLY with science, or is it with americas 
government?
comments.author: Flarus

comments.text:
I don't know how this conversation turned to GMOs but I did a report on it 
so why not.

Do you really think companies like Monsanto are creating these crops for 
the good of poor countries? How will self sterilizing crops benefit poor 
farmers, who are use to saving seeds after each harvest. 

Monsanto has PATENTED LIFE. They track every farmers move for violations 
and take them to court. Most farmers who are taken to court cannot afford 
to fight them and are forced to cough up. Many unwillingly change to GMO 
seeds after neighboring GMO fields pollinate their non GMO crops. This has 
happened primarily in America, but left unchecked Monsanto will soon 
dominate the worlds GM market. 90%of GM soybeans and 80% if GM corn come 
from Monsanto. 70% of the food you see in US supermarkets contain GMOs.

But GMOs could never harm us health wise right? It's not like the 7 high 
ranking officials in the FDA who use to work with Monsanto would ever let 
anything bad slip past them.
comments.author: ADubey

top_comment.text: Does japans population decrease because they kill off every third child?﻿
top_comment.author: RuggedALAN

comments.text:
+Cody Ben
China's relaxing of the one-child policy, which was announced last year, 
allowed people in rural areas to have a second child if the first was a 
girl and any couple where one parent was an only child to have two children 
(relaxed from the previous requirement that both had to be an only child).  
China's goal is to have zero population growth, so it's unlikely that 
anyone will ever be allowed to have more than two children without 
sanctions unless there are special circumstances (such as one child having 
a severe mental or physical impairment, which is currently grounds to allow 
a second child).
comments.author: Ryn Win

comments.text:
+Quyen Pham
 Sex selective abortion is not the same as killing every third newborn 
though, which is what +RuggedALAN thought was going on in Japan. 

While infanticide does happen to some small extent in every part of the 
world (and it is disproportionally high in China), there has never been an 
*institutionalized* practice like this that I know of.   Also, to my 
knowledge, the one child policy is not entirely compulsory in China, just 
very strongly encouraged by preferential treatment for those who follow it, 
and sanctions for those who don't.  I've also heard stories of women who 
decide to have a second child being bullied by their community into 
aborting it. Sex selective abortion, however, is strongly discouraged (I 
think actually it's technically illegal), and families in rural areas whose 
first child is a girl can apply to have a second child without sanctions.
comments.author: Ryn Win

comments.text:
+Quyen Pham China has eased on the one-child policy allowing many children 
in rural lands and two in urban areas. Otherwise Ryn Win hit Japan's issue 
on the nose.
comments.author: Cody Ben

comments.text:
+RuggedALAN Well China is in Asia though.. but they're the only one to do 
such thing. Glad that you finally got out of the misunderstanding :)
comments.author: Quyen Pham

comments.text:
+Ryn Win thank you for taking the time to explain that. This whole time i 
thought asians were killing off their newborns
comments.author: RuggedALAN

comments.text:
Actually it seems have more to do with the fact that, traditionally, once a 
woman got married, she was expected to quit her job and devote all her time 
to being a mother and housewife while the husband devoted his time to a 
brutal work culture in order to support a family that he wasn't able to 
spend much time with.   Women feel like they have to choose between having 
a career and having a family, while men are faced with having to 
independently support a family on a single income that, in the current 
economy, is unlikely to increase significantly by the time children come 
into the picture.

The result of this is that both men and women are leery of the picture of 
family life that they've been presented with; though things have, by 
necessity, been changing to become more supportive of women continuing to 
work after marriage.
comments.author: Ryn Win

 Japan also had a big baby boom after WW2 with couples having 3 to 8

competitive society, increased living costs,... . Research "Japanese 
demographic death spiral". Nowadays Japanese culture is also a factor cause

systematic way by their parents, zip, nada... Also it would have to have

comments.text:
As you hate fellow humans you should take your self away 2m underground.So

there is enough nuke for everyone, so yes we can

obama said it

comments.author: Aleks Ich

comments.text:
+Zachary Rodriguez People do.  Why do you think there is a big push for 
renewable energy and more efficient crop growth?  

As for the whole "Humanity will use up the Earth's resources!", species do 
that.  It's the way of nature.  A population grows until it meets it's 
environment's caring capacity at which the population plateaus.  The reason 
the human population keeps growing, as Sacratease said, is because humans 
keep finding a way to expand the caring capacity.

And before anyone criticizes me for saying we should do nothing, I'm not 
saying that; I'm saying that we will do something that will solve our 
population problem and then we'll move on to solving the next 
<sarcasm>apocalyptic</sarcasm> event.
comments.author: BionicKing

comments.text:
+Sacratease If only more people thought along the same lines you do. 
Unfortunately many don't, but perhaps enough do to make the changes needed. 
At the very least, those of us without power could support them or follow 
their examples.
comments.author: Zachary Rodriguez

comments.text:
We have always run up against the problem of limited resources for 
expanding populations. When we were hunter-gatherers, the solution was to 
move to agriculture. When there was a shortage of fertile lands in some 
region we moved to technology.

At every step of the way we had a choice: war, infanticide, or intelligent 
solutions. We need to trust human intelligence to come to good solutions 
and not cry about limited resources.
comments.author: Sacratease

comments.text:
if we continue the next 50 years with that amount of ppl on the earth, all

there is a book that describes that the earth can only support around 1 to

comments.text:
Well I know this is going to be hard to hear/read this for you but there 
are none on the chart, I have two explanations why.

1. When the population pyramid been first used (maybe as early as 1950's), 
the social norm at the time was male and female. Adding other genders to 
the chart will greatly use time, funds and resources to retroactively move 
people around and impassible to ask what gender were they when the person 
is already dead and gone. Resulting the databases to be broken for 
forecasting population.

2. The population pyramids counts only the physical state of the gender, 
not mental or emotional, This is because there are biological differences 
between between man and women that the data needed to focus problems that 
an area can face. Say there is a disease that targets only one gender, the 
world heath organizations got to take the best estimate to produce and 
supply any medications for that area and reduce fatalities. If the other 
gender is in the chart, they will either make too little for the few that 
is not considered male or make too much that the time spent making them 
will use travel time, increasing the wait times for the ill.
comments.author: blue2x2x

captions.text: Russia, with the largest territory in the world,
has roughly the same total population as Nigeria,
a country 1/16 its size.
But this similarity won't last long.
One of the populations is rapidly growing,
while the other is slowly declining.
What can this tell us about the two countries?
Population statistics are some of the most important data
social scientists and policy experts have to work with.
But understanding a country's situation
and making accurate predictions
requires knowing not just the total size of the population
but its internal characteristics,
such as age and gender distribution.
So, how can we keep track of all that data
in a way that makes it easy to comprehend?
Complex data is more easily interpreted
through visualization,
and one of the ways that demographers represent
the internal distribution of a population
is the population pyramid.
Here, the data is divided by gender
with females on one side and males on the other.
The population numbers are shown
for each five-year age interval,
starting from 0-4
and continuing up to 100 and up.
These intervals are grouped together
into pre-reproductive (0-14),
reproductive (15-44),
and post-reproductive years (45 and up).
Such a population pyramid can be a powerful predictor
of future population trends.
For example,
Rwanda's population pyramid shows it to be a fast-growing country,
with most of the population
being in the youngest age groups at the bottom of the pyramid.
The number will grow rapidly in the coming years.
As today's children reach their reproductive years
and have children of their own,
the total population is almost certain to double
within the next few decades.
For our second example,
let's look at Canada,
where most of the population is clustered
around the middle of the graph.
Because there are less people
in the pre-reproductive age groups
than there are in the reproductive ones,
the population will grow more slowly,
as the number of people reaching their reproductive years decreases.
Finally, let's look at Japan.
Because the majority of its population
is in its post-reproductive years
and the number of people is smaller
at each younger interval,
this means that at current rates of reproduction
the population will begin to decline
as fewer and fewer people reach reproductive age.
Comparing these three population pyramids
side by side
shows us three different stages
in a demographic transition,
as a country moves from a pre-industrial society
to one with an industrial
or post-industrial economy.
Countries that have only recently begun
the process of industrialization
typically see an increase in life expectancy
and a fall in child mortality rates
as a result of improvements
in medicine, sanitation, and food supply.
While birth rates remain constant,
leading to a population boom.
Developing countries that are farther along
in the industrialization process
begin to see a fall in birth rates,
due to factors such as
increased education and opportunities for women outside of child-rearing
and a move from rural to urban living
that makes having large families
less economically advantageous.
Finally, countries in advanced stages of industrialization
reach a point
where both birth and death rates are low,
and the population remains stable
or even begins to decline.
Now, let's take a look at the projected population pyramids
for the same three countries in 2050.
What do these tell us
about the expected changes
in each country's population,
and what kinds of factors
can alter the shape of these future pyramids?
A population pyramid can be useful
not only as a predictor of a country's future
but as a record of its past.
Russia's population pyramid
still bears the scars of World War II,
which explains both the fewer numbers of elderly men
compared to elderly women
and the relatively sudden population increase
as soldiers returned from the war
and normal life resumed.
China's population pyramid
reflects the establishment of the one child policy
35 years before,
which prevented a population boom
such as that of Rwanda
but also led to sex-selective abortions,
resulting in more male children than female children.
Finally, the pyramid for the United States
shows the baby boom that followed World War II.
As you can see,
population pyramids tell us far more
about a country
than just a set of numbers,
by showing both where it's been
and where it's headed
within a single image.
And in today's increasingly interconnected world,
facing issues such as food shortages,
ecological threats, and economic disparities,
it is increasingly important
for both scientists and policy makers
to have a rich and complex understanding
of populations and the factors affecting them.

title: Population pyramids: Powerful predictors of the future - Kim Preshoff
